title: How can we improve energy efficiency? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is going to be a very short answer for a very large topic. Google ACEEE. The American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy is the premier advocate for efficiency in this country, and collates and consolidates a lot of the best thinking globally on the subject of efficiency. In the U.S. we basically have two major approaches to efficiency implementation, and a larger number of less well appreciated avenues to promote research and development. Our utilities run efficiency programs. The programs are expected to demonstrate cost-effectiveness through proper use of a few standardized economic tests. The implementation is left to state policy or the individual utility, and it is pretty good, but there are some exceptions. More important than the exceptions, the utilities spend about $8 billion per year and create savings worth about $30 - $35 billion per year. Each year’s savings installs hardware which lasts anywhere from a couple of years to a couple of decades. You can also google Consortium for Energy Efficiency, but their reports are less helpful to the layperson than ACEEE and some other organizations. The other major approach is Federal appliance and energy standards. These standards are a group of policies, not a single set or organized program, and they affect everything from vehicles to lightbulbs. Federal standards are raised when all major manufacturers have the ability to produce a competitive product that meets a proposed new standard, and the standard guarantees economic savings in excess of any added cost. Often the act of setting the standard causes the cost of the more efficient product to drop toward the price of the less efficient product which was displaced. Refrigerators are one of the best examples, but these standards have affected the majority of appliances and home energy-consuming products over the years. In 2019 the utility programs are savings approximately twice as much as the Federal standards in terms of new reductions per year. It is best to regard the utility programs as driving efficiency, while the Federal standards sweep up the bottom of the barrel by eliminating the worst products. Some technologies thrive and become more efficient without standards. Some technologies and practices are pretty far out of the experience of ordinary people, such as increased efficiency for generators, transmission equipment, and smart grid management of voltage on transmission lines. And efficiency gains are a constant objective for wind and solar manufacturers. You can spend a lifetime learning about efficiency. I know because I’ve been doing it for 35 years.
